results.name: Zero-one fractional-part array for the golden ratio; a rectangular array T by antidiagonals.
comment: See A187950 for connections to left-shifted sums of the infinite Fibonacci word.
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 1..100 of antidiagonals, flattened
formula: T(n,k) = {nr} + {kr} - {nr+kr}, where r=(1+sqrt(5))/2 and { } denotes fractional part;, i.e., {x} = x - floor(x).
example: The antidiagonals form a triangle with these first six rows:
mathematica: Table[T[n-k+1, k], {n,1,10}, {k,1,n}]//Flatten (* modified by _G. C. Greubel_, May 30 2019 *)
program: for(n=1,10, for(k=1,n, print1(T(n-k+1,k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, May 30 2019
(MAGMA) r:=(1+Sqrt(5))/2; [[Floor((n+1)*r)-Floor((n-k+1)*r)-Floor(k*r): k in [1..n]]: n in [1..10]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, May 30 2019
def T(n, k): return floor((n+k)*golden_ratio) - floor(n*golden_ratio) - floor(k*golden_ratio)
[[T(n-k+1, k) for k in (1..n)] for n in (1..12)] # _G. C. Greubel_, May 30 2019
